pred: The GhostVLAD approach is a pooling strategy used in language identification tasks, inspired by the NetVLAD method for place recognition. It aims to aggregate local features from ResNet-based deep neural networks into global features while excluding noisy or irrelevant content from the ghost clusters.
answers: extension of the NetVLAD, adds Ghost clusters along with the NetVLAD clusters
An extension of NetVLAD which replaces hard assignment-based clustering with soft assignment-based clustering with the additon o fusing Ghost clusters to deal with noisy content.

pred: The ensemble method used in the article works by combining the predictions of multiple models, each of which is trained on a different dataset. The models are selected based on their performance on the validation dataset, and the ensemble is formed by averaging the predictions from the constituent models. The authors used a greedy ensemble approach, starting with the best-performing model and iteratively adding other models that improve the ensemble's performance on the validation dataset.

pred: The authors propose a novel multimodal dual recurrent encoder (MDRE) model that combines audio and text sequences in their RNN. The model uses two RNNs to encode data from the audio signal and textual inputs independently. The audio-RNN encodes MFCC features from the audio signal using a recurrent encoder (ARE), while the text-RNN encodes the word sequence of the transcript using a text recurrent encoder (TRE). The final hidden states of the audio-RNN and text-RNN are then passed through another fully connected neural network layer to form a combined representation.
answers: combines the information from these sources using a feed-forward neural model
encodes the information from audio and text sequences using dual RNNs and then combines the information from these sources using a feed-forward neural model

pred: The new context representation is obtained by splitting the sentence into three disjoint regions based on the two relation arguments, and then processing these regions with two independent convolutional and max-pooling layers. The resulting results are concatenated to form the sentence representation.
answers: They use two independent convolutional and max-pooling layers on (1) a combination of the left context, the left entity and the middle context; and (2) a combination of the middle context, the right entity and the right context. They concatenated the two results after pooling to get the new context representation.

pred:
The baselines mentioned in the article are:

1. Vanilla ST baseline: A model trained from scratch on the ST-TED corpus.
2. Pre-training baselines:
a. Encoder pre-training: The ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model.
b. Decoder pre-training: The ST decoder is initialized from an MT model.
c. Encoder-decoder pre-training: Both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained.
3. Multi-task baselines:
a. One-to-many setting: The model is trained with $\alpha_{st}=0.75$ and $\alpha_{asr}=0.25$ or $\alpha_{mt}=0.25$.
b. Many-to-one setting: The model is trained with $\alpha_{st}=0.6, \alpha_{asr}=0.2$ and $\alpha_{mt}=0.2$.
c. Many-to-many setting: The model is trained with $\alpha_{st}=0.6, \alpha_{asr}=0.2$ and $\alpha_{mt}=0.2$.
4. Many-to-many+pre-training: A model trained as a many-to-many multi-task model where the encoders and decoders are derived from pre-trained ASR and MT models.
5. Triangle+pre-train: A model that combines an ST decoder with an ASR encoder-decoder model, where the ASR decoder is initialized from the pre-trained ASR model.
answers: Vanilla ST baseline, encoder pre-training, in which the ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model, decoder pre-training, in which the ST decoder is initialized from an MT model, encoder-decoder pre-training, where both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained, many-to-many multi-task model where the encoders and decoders are derived from pre-trained ASR and MT models, Triangle+pre-train: BIBREF18 DBLP:conf/naacl/AnastasopoulosC18 proposed a triangle multi-task strategy for speech translation
Vanilla ST baseline, Pre-training baselines, Multi-task baselines, Many-to-many+pre-training, Triangle+pre-train

Vanilla ST baseline: The vanilla ST BIBREF9 has only a speech encoder and a decoder. It is trained from scratch on the ST-TED corpus.

Pre-training baselines: We conduct three pre-training baseline experiments: 1) encoder pre-training, in which the ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model; 2) decoder pre-training, in which the ST decoder is initialized from an MT model; and 3) encoder-decoder pre-training, where both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained. The ASR model has the same architecture with vanilla ST model, trained on the mixture of ST-TED and TED-LIUM2 corpus. The MT model has a text encoder and decoder with the same architecture of which in TCEN. It is first trained on WMT data (out-of-domain) and then fine-tuned on in-domain data.

Multi-task baselines: We also conduct three multi-task baseline experiments including one-to-many setting, many-to-one setting, and many-to-many setting. In the first two settings, we train the model with $\alpha _{st}=0.75$ while $\alpha _{asr}=0.25$ or $\alpha _{mt}=0.25$. For many-to-many setting, we use $\alpha _{st}=0.6, \alpha _{asr}=0.2$ and $\alpha _{mt}=0.2$.. For MT task, we use only in-domain data.

Many-to-many+pre-training: We train a many-to-many multi-task model where the encoders and decoders are derived from pre-trained ASR and MT models.

pred:
The authors of the article presented a novel task of generating personalized recipes from incomplete input specifications and user histories. They explored a large-scale transformer-based language model and found it to be surprisingly expressive and fluent in creative and conditional long-text generation. They introduced a new dataset of 180K+ recipes and 700K+ user reviews for this task and introduced new evaluation strategies for generation quality in instructional texts.

Their results showed that personalized models outperformed baseline models in BPE perplexity, BLEU-1/4, and ROUGE-L. The Prior Name model performed the best in BPE perplexity and generated more diverse and diverse recipes. The authors also introduced a set of automatic coherence measures for instructional texts and personalization metrics to support their claims.
answers: average recipe-level coherence scores of 1.78-1.82, human evaluators preferred personalized model outputs to baseline 63% of the time

pred: The combination of rewards for reinforcement learning in the irony generation model is designed to control both irony accuracy and sentiment preservation. The rewards are defined as the harmonic mean of the irony reward and the sentiment reward, which encourages the model to focus on both aspects while preserving the content of the input sentence.
answers: irony accuracy, sentiment preservation
irony accuracy and sentiment preservation

pred:
The tagging scheme employed in the article is a combination of two tags, INLINEFORM0 and INLINEFORM1, where:

1. INLINEFORM0 tag means the current word is not a pun.
2. INLINEFORM1 tag means the current word is a pun.

If a sentence does not contain any puns, all words will be tagged with INLINEFORM0 or INLINEFORM1, respectively. If a sentence contains a pun, the word corresponding to INLINEFORM1 is the pun.
answers: A new tagging scheme that tags the words before and after the pun as well as the pun words.
a new tagging scheme consisting of three tags, namely { INLINEFORM0 }

pred: Robustness of a model is defined as its ability to handle unbalanced labeled features and class distributions without significantly degrading performance. In the article, this is measured by comparing the performance of different regularization terms and methods on various datasets with different unbalanced labeled features and class distributions. The model is considered robust if it can maintain or improve its performance when facing these challenges.
answers: ability to accurately classify texts even when the amount of prior knowledge for different classes is unbalanced, and when the class distribution of the dataset is unbalanced

pred:
The methods mentioned in the article for finding examples of biases and unwarranted inferences include:

1. Manually inspecting the descriptions and identifying any stereotypical or biased language.
2. Analyzing the use of adjectives and other words to mark individuals who deviate from the norm.
3. Examining the Flickr30K Entities dataset to identify patterns of ethnicity/race marking.
4. Applying Louvain clustering to the coreference graph of the Flickr30K dataset to identify clusters of expressions that refer to similar entities.
5. Using part-of-speech information to see which adjectives are most commonly used for particular nouns.

However, the article also mentions that it is difficult to automatically detect bias from the data, so manual inspection and analysis are necessary.
answers: spot patterns by just looking at a collection of images, tag all descriptions with part-of-speech information, I applied Louvain clustering
Looking for adjectives marking the noun "baby" and also looking for most-common adjectives related to certain nouns using POS-tagging

pred:
The authors experimented with various summarization algorithms, including:

1. ILP-based summarization, which used Integer Linear Programming (ILP) to identify important text fragments or phrases and create a summary.
2. Sumy package algorithms, which included a common parameter for the number of sentences to be included in the final summary.
3. K-means clustering, which was used to group sentences based on their POS-tagged form.
4. CLUTO and Carrot2 Lingo clustering algorithms, which were used to discover meaningful clusters within the sentence classes.
5. Logistic Regression classifier, which was used for topical classification of sentences.
6. SVM with ADWS kernel, which was used for non-topical classification of sentences.
answers: LSA, TextRank, LexRank and ILP-based summary.
LSA, TextRank, LexRank

pred: The weights are dynamically adjusted using a decaying factor $(1-p)$ in proportion to the number of training examples. This factor is multiplied with the probability $p$ to obtain the weight for each example. The weight dynamically changes as training proceeds, making the model more attentive to hard-to-classify examples and less focused on easy examples.
answers: One can think $(1-p_{i1})$ as a weight associated with each example, which changes as training proceeds. The intuition of changing $p_{i1}$ to $(1-p_{i1}) p_{i1}$ is to push down the weight of easy examples. For easy examples whose probability are approaching 0 or 1, $(1-p_{i1}) p_{i1}$ makes the model attach significantly less focus to them. Figure FIGREF23 gives gives an explanation from the perspective in derivative: the derivative of $\frac{(1-p)p}{1+(1-p)p}$ with respect to $p$ approaches 0 immediately after $p$ approaches 0, which means the model attends less to examples once they are correctly classified.
associates each training example with a weight in proportion to $(1-p)$, and this weight dynamically changes as training proceeds

pred: The proposed strategies, KG-A2C-chained and KG-A2C-Explore, were able to pass the bottleneck in Zork1 at a score of 40, where the player is eaten by a "grue" if they do not first light a lamp. The lamp must be lit many steps after first being encountered, in a different section of the game. These strategies were found to be more efficient in exploring the game and surpassing bottlenecks compared to previous methods.
answers: Reward of 11.8 for the A2C-chained model, 41.8 for the KG-A2C-chained model, 40 for A2C-Explore and 44 for KG-A2C-Explore.
KG-A2C-chained and KG-A2C-Explore both pass the bottleneck of a score of 40

pred: A single model in this context consists of a monolingual model and a crosslingual latent variable (CLV). The monolingual model is trained for a specific language, while the CLV captures role alignments across different languages. The model combines the monolingual model and the CLV to make predictions for unseen roles in a multilingual setting.

pred: Masking words in the decoder is helpful because it allows the decoder to focus on generating contextually relevant words, fluent, and natural sequences. By masking words one by one, the decoder is forced to predict the most appropriate word given the context, which helps it learn to generate better context representations and improve the overall quality of the generated text.
answers: ecause this process is similar to the cloze task in BERT's pre-train process, therefore by using the ability of the contextual language model the decoder can generate more fluent and natural sequences.

pred: The political bias of different sources is included in the model by assigning a political bias label to each news outlet, following a procedure described in the article. This label is then used to balance the classification of disinformation and mainstream news.
answers: By assigning a political bias label to each news article and training only on left-biased or right-biased outlets of both disinformation and mainstream domains

we also account for political biases inherent to different news sources, referring to the procedure proposed in BIBREF2 to label different outlets. Overall we show that we are able to classify credible vs non-credible diffusion networks (and consequently news articles) with high accuracy (AUROC up to 94%), even when accounting for the political bias of sources (and training only on left-biased or right-biased articles). We observe that the layer of mentions alone conveys useful information for the classification, denoting a different usage of this functionality when sharing news belonging to the two news domains. We also show that most discriminative features, which are relative to the breadth and depth of largest cascades in different layers, are the same across the two countries.

pred:
The article describes several experiments, including:

1. Pretraining with auto-encoder and back-translation to build up language models for both styles.
2. Reinforcement learning to train the model to transfer sentences from one style to another.
3. Evaluation of the quality of the generated sentences using a pre-trained binary irony classifier and two pre-trained sentiment classifiers for non-ironic and ironic sentences.
4. Comparison of the model with other state-of-art generative models.
5. Human evaluation of the generated sentences by four annotators.
answers: Irony Classifier, Sentiment Classifier for Irony, Sentiment Classifier for Non-irony, transformation from ironic sentences to non-ironic sentences

pred: Gaussian-masked directional multi-head attention is a variant of multi-head attention that captures the representation of input sentences by dividing queries, keys, and values into different heads and getting information from different subspaces. It uses a Gaussian weight matrix to map the localness relationship between each two characters and a Hadamard product of the Gaussian weight matrix and the score matrix to focus on the attention.
answers: pays attentions to adjacent characters and casts a localness relationship between the characters as a fixed Gaussian weight assuming the weight relies on the distance between characters

Gaussian-masked directional attention can be described as a function to map queries and key-value pairs to the representation of input, Gaussian-masked directional attention expects to pay attention to the adjacent characters of each positions and cast the localness relationship between characters as a fix Gaussian weight for attention, Gaussian weight only relys on the distance between characters
